name: getNumericDate
description: Returns a real number whose integer part represents the number of days since the EPOCH and whose fractional part represents the time value expressed in hours then divided by 24. NOTE: Lucee (and ACF) uses 12/30/1899 00:00:00 as it's epoch time. See links below.

params.name: arg1
params.description: A datetime object or a date-parsable String.

examples.title: Convert a date string to a numeric date - Tag Syntax
examples.description: This numeric date represents the number of days between December 30, 1899 and January 1, 2008.

links.title: What is Epoch?
links.description: A description of what general "Epoch" means in computers, and how it can differ on various systems. NOTE: ColdFusion doesn't generally rely on UNIX Epoch of 1/1/1970.

links.title: Why does ColdFusion (Lucee and Adobe) use 12/30/1899 00:00:00 as "Epoch time"?
links.description: A brief comment on how Allaire probably came to use 12/30/1899 as Epoch. For more history, view the answer's Source link.

links.title: If you want to more of the "Why" of the various versions of "Epoch time"...
links.description: This is a MSDN link that discusses different types of Timestamps and how they relate to an Epoch.
